posts.post_content:
Even if you don't plan on using it, at least add it in as a sideboard utility. It blows mill decks out of the water.   
  
If you think that hard casting it is too difficult, then you don't know how to use the set. Spawns and Eldrazi lands make up most of the mana cost. that is what's supposed to happen.

posts.post_content:
@Johnald: You're right on all counts, except that you're forgetting that Wizards R&D spends too much time worrying about Limited and not enough about other formats. In their minds, Emrakul is the RoE equivilant of an Overrun in M10, only more important to the plot and to their profits, so it's a mythic instead of uncommon. In both cases, the moment the card drops, the game ends, almost always.
  
   
@SleetFox: I don't think it's possible for an immortal creature the size of a mountain, with a physical form that was forced on it by a trio of planeswalkers aeons after its creation/formation/whatever-happened, to ever have developed reproductive organs, so I'd say that Emrakul doesn't have a gender.
posts.html:
@Johnald: You're right on all counts, except that you're forgetting that Wizards R&D spends too much time worrying about Limited and not enough about other formats. In their minds, Emrakul is the RoE equivilant of an Overrun in M10, only more important to the plot and to their profits, so it's a mythic instead of uncommon. In both cases, the moment the card drops, the game ends, almost always.

@SleetFox: I don't think it's possible for an immortal creature the size of a mountain, with a physical form that was forced on it by a trio of planeswalkers aeons after its creation/formation/whatever-happened, to ever have developed reproductive organs, so I'd say that Emrakul doesn't have a gender.

Posted By: statiefreez (4/17/2010 7:38:35 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Does anybody remember when Darksteel Colossus and Phyrexian Dreadnought were considered to be some of the most powerful creatures ever printed (not efficient necessarily, just really big and powerful).  
  
These make them look like nothing.  
Kozilek and Ulamog are most likely more powerful than Colossus, and they cost roughly the same.  
And there is no contest for Emrakul.  
  
The worst thing is, as things stand in Standard, you'll be seeing Kozilek and Ulamog turn 5-6, and Emrakul only 2-3 turns later (if you survive that long).  
  
You'll be seeing them turn 3 or sooner in Extended with Hypergenesis Cascade.
posts.html:
Does anybody remember when Darksteel Colossus and Phyrexian Dreadnought were considered to be some of the most powerful creatures ever printed (not efficient necessarily, just really big and powerful).

These make them look like nothing.
Kozilek and Ulamog are most likely more powerful than Colossus, and they cost roughly the same.
And there is no contest for Emrakul.

The worst thing is, as things stand in Standard, you'll be seeing Kozilek and Ulamog turn 5-6, and Emrakul only 2-3 turns later (if you survive that long).

You'll be seeing them turn 3 or sooner in Extended with Hypergenesis Cascade.

Posted By: True_Smog (4/19/2010 12:03:51 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
That's one heck of a mana cost, but you get what you pay for. This may well supplant Darksteel Colossus as the go-to fetch card when putting things from your library into play (with [Tooth and Nail](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Tooth and Nail), for example). Even minus the extra turn, this guy is beefier, has evasion, and, unless they can come out with seven fliers a turn, impervious to chump blocking. Just attacking will do some real damage, whether he gets through or not. Fun fun fun.  
This is a true Rolls-Royce type creature, but it makes me a little sad that green no longer has the largest creature. Krosan Colossus just felt...*right*.
posts.html:

Just attacking will do some real damage, whether he gets through or not. Fun fun fun.
This is a true Rolls-Royce type creature, but it makes me a little sad that green no longer has the largest creature. Krosan Colossus just felt...right.

Posted By: ClockworkSwordfish (4/19/2010 7:28:34 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: These legendary Eldrazi are wreaking my favourite deck style (which is mill/control). I like them though. An uncounterable [Time Warp](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Time Warp) with a major wreaking ball body and multiple murderous abilities is always awesome. I have found that a well timed [Telemin Performance](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Telemin Performance) can turn the tides of the game and maybe a [Mindbreak Trap](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mindbreak Trap) can be profitable. Also I have used [Gather Specimens](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Gather Specimens) to get my opponents big guys. [Sadistic Sacrement](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sadistic Sacrement) could work, especially if its kicked.
posts.html:
These legendary Eldrazi are wreaking my favourite deck style (which is mill/control). I like them though. I have found that a well timed Telemin Performance can turn the tides of the game and maybe a Mindbreak Trap can be profitable. Also I have used Gather Specimens to get my opponents big guys. posts.post_content:
@Asinine-Ultimatum:  
  
Prison Term cannot target Emrakul, as Prison Term is a colored spell, and enchanting a creature counts as targeting it. It's the same logical thinking that means you cannot enchant or equip a creature that has Shroud.
posts.html:
@Asinine-Ultimatum:

Prison Term cannot target Emrakul, as Prison Term is a colored spell, and enchanting a creature counts as targeting it. It's the same logical thinking that means you cannot enchant or equip a creature that has Shroud.

Posted By: allmighty_abacus (5/25/2010 2:52:34 PM)

posts.post_content:
From what I understand this is replacing [Progenitus](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Progenitus) as the win condition for [Polymorph](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Polymorph) decks. My friend built one recently, with this as the only creature, token producers for the morph fodder, and a bunch of counters to protect the combo. Of course the problem with such a deck is that even my sloppily constructed red/green Allies deck rolls right over it if he doesn't manage to pull his combo off by the fifth turn. Conversely, on the occasions he does manage to get it out and attack with it, it's pretty much game over.
  
   
I've been thinking of other ways to deal with this guy other than the obvious one of killing the opponent before he gets it in play. In standard, there are several options, such as [Day of Judgment](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Day of Judgment) or [Planar Cleansing](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Planar Cleansing), which, ironically, his weaker brother Ulamog would be immune to. [Sarkhan the Mad](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sarkhan the Mad) can turn him into a harmless 5/5 dragon, but Sarkhan Vol... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

posts.post_content:
Annihilator 6... seriously? Not that annihilator isn't the most unfair and overpowered game mechanic in this block... but annihilator is the most unfair and overpowered game mechanic in this block.  
  
The thing that really gets me is that you can just put this guy out with an [Elvish Piper](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Elvish Piper) or [Dramatic Entrance](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Dramatic Entrance) and the only ill effect to you is that you don't get an extra turn. A turn-five 15/15 flyer that can't be countered, and has annihilator 6 is just a little bit stupid.
